history.content:
It really depends on what you want to do in industry. If you want to be the circuit designer who is designing the RF and/or communications circuits, then you need all those circuits courses along with 142. However, if you're focus is more on just getting some intellectual breath, I would recommend 105. It is an intense course, but it can give you cursory understanding of transistor based circuits. Unless you plan on going into IC design, 140, 130, 151 are not really required. 105 will introduce you to Cadence and HSPICE. If you really want to do something in digital design (ie design the DSP basebands of radios or things along those lines) then you should also take 151, where you will learn about Verilog.

As for the do you need technical breath to be employable? I have no idea. Will it probably be useful anyway? Yes. (From someone who's taken all the circuits courses listed and 120/123/126)

Technical breadth is good for everyone. For someone who wants to root in communications/control (which in the modern day going forward at the bachelor's level also *includes* signal processing and, critically, optimization and machine learning), the three most important breadth courses are probably (in order)

  1. 149: embedded cyberphysical systems. This is a core software engineering course that hits many of the skills involved in actually putting together a real system that interacts with the physical world. 
  2. 151: digital design. This is a core circuits course that makes sure that you understand what is involved in actually realizing very high-performance designs by leveraging hardware appropriately. To really hit this area, you should probably take the 290 course that builds on 151 and talks about VLSI realizations of signal-processing/communication/machine-learning. That's where you will see how the realities of implementation constraints force engineers to actually rework the algorithms themselves to function much better.
  3. 105: microelectronics. This is a core analog circuits course at the intro level. If you don't know this, you will have a hard time even following any conversation that engages with the analog constraints. But again, it is at the 142 level where this really gets you over the hump to be able to meaningfully participate in serious design conversations around communications in particular. This particular breadth is more important for communications, and secondarily for control. The interesting thing that most people don't realize is that understanding how op-amps work and the like actually involves understanding more control. So courses like 140 actually can deepen your understanding of control. 

Other breadths like 162 (operating systems) are also important. Classes like 130 provide nice cultural context, but aren't nearly at the same level of importance as those listed above or 162.

The fact that OP didn't list 127 and 189 shows a gap in the technical core for someone interested in comm/control. These are arguably *more* important than both 123 and 122/168 from your list. 

At the end of the day, these are areas where the typical entry-level job usually takes someone with an MS from elsewhere. Are 7 upper-div EECS courses enough? Barely.  At 10 (corresponding to 2 EECS techs per term for 8 years - 6 lower-divs), you can do it and compete with MS students from elsewhere. At a 5th-year MS with another 4 courses, you can generally completely dominate the MS-level competition from elsewhere.

I've taken/plan to take the standard communications fare of 120/123/126/128 and will definitely do 122 and (121 if they ever offer it again!) before I graduate. 

However, I feel like as an EE major, I should have a level of understanding of circuits at a much higher level than 16B. A lot of the EE jobs I see in RF and related fields seem to require design skills that I don't currently have (I have no idea what Cadence, HSPICE, and Verilog do but they seem to be everywhere).

At most other more traditional EE schools, all EE's are required to take intro upper div classes in electromagnetics, transistors, digital and analog design, and signals, but here we don't have these requirements. But the problem is that all of our "intro" upper divs are notoriously intense. If I wanted to get that technical breadth here, I would need 117, 130, 105, 140 AND 151 on top of the signals classes I have already taken. Besides 117, I hear all those classes are SUPER intense (EE doesn't really have "light" upperdivs like 188 or 168). Those classes will suck up my entire senior year and make it really tough (I have 1 year left). I would rather spend senior year doing EE22x grad classes because it's the subset of the field I'm interested in.

Do I need technical breadth to be employable, or is my current course history enough?

(I did a little more research and apparently 130, 140 and 151 are cross-listed as grad classes, which scares me even more! These are the INTRO upper divs for transistors, analog and digital!)
history.subject: Importance of EE105/130/140 for a communications/controls focused EE major

However, I feel like as an EE major, I should have a level of understanding of circuits and transistors at a much higher level than 16B. A lot of the EE jobs I see in RF and related fields seem to require design skills that I don't currently have (I have no idea what Cadence, HSPICE, and Verilog do but they seem to be everywhere).

At most other more traditional EE schools, all EE's are required to take intro upper div classes in electromagnetics, transistors, digital and analog design, and signals, but here we don't have these requirements. But the problem is that all of our "intro" upper divs are notoriously intense. If I wanted to get that technical breadth here, I would need 117, 130, 105, 140 AND 150 on top of the signals classes I have already taken. Besides 117, I hear all those classes are SUPER intense (EE doesn't really have "light" upperdivs like 188 or 168). Those classes will suck up my entire senior year and make it really tough (I have 1 year left). I would rather spend senior year doing EE22x grad classes because it's the subset of the field I'm interested in.

Do I need breadth to get a job in RF or a similar field, or is my current course history enough?
